body: `strip_prefix` will effectively work exactly the same as your `use_subdir` suggestion. So fixing this is really as simple as forwarding an argument from `git_override` to `git_repository`. See code for [`git_override()`](https://cs.opensource.google/bazel/bazel/+/master:src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/bazel/bzlmod/ModuleFileGlobals.java;drc=b83b48c8d4e43546f69d5b5bd79031ab25c179ee;l=969) the API and [`GitOverride`](https://cs.opensource.google/bazel/bazel/+/master:src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/bazel/bzlmod/GitOverride.java;drc=f0ab82da5eac8fbedabf253d07692db7a7d0c648;l=24) its backing data object.

issue.title: Add `strip_prefix` arg to bzlmod's `git_override`

labels.name: team-ExternalDeps
labels.description: External dependency handling, remote repositiories, WORKSPACE file.

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

issue.body:
Add `strip_prefix` arg go bzlmod's `git_override` and pass it down to `git_repository`.

This allows users to work with git repositories that have other Bazel modules in subdirectories.
A prime example of such is the `rules_python`](https://github.com/bazelbuild/rules_python) repo:

```
./rules_python
├── MODULE.bazel       # available on BCR as "rules_python"
└── gazelle
    └── MODULE.bazel   # available on BCR as "rules_python_gazelle_plugin"
```


Fixes #22076.

RELNOTES:
bzlmod `git_repository` now accepts the `strip_prefix` arg and passes it to the underlying `git_repository` call.

issue.title: [7.2.0] Have MODULE's `git_override` support using a nested path
